sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: Authenticity and provenance of the specimen

The fossil shark specimen described here was discovered in 2012 in situ in the Vallecillo quarry area (Nuevo León State, northeastern Mexico) by an unknown quarryman, then secured, collected and prepared by one of us (M.A.G.G.). Finally, Mauricio Fernandez Garza (San Pedro Garza García) purchased the specimen in order to assign it an Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia (INAH) registration number and to house and display it in a new public museum (Museo La Milarca in San Pedro Garza García MMSP, Nuevo León State, Mexico; scheduled opening in 2021), where it will be accessible upon request. All of us intensively and thoroughly checked the specimen and the limestone surface by direct investigation with a hand lens (e.g., to look for teeth) and macrophotography; therefore, we can formally state that the specimen is 1) authentic and not a composite fossil, and 2) originates from one of the Vallecillo quarries located in the western part of the limestone exploitation area.
The Vallecillo plattenkalk and stratigraphic position of the specimen

At Vallecillo, lower Turonian platy limestone (plattenkalk) has yielded many other open marine vertebrates, including elasmobranchs ( Ptychodus sp., Cretoxyrhina mantelli ), actinopterygians ( Araripichthys sp., Tselfatia formosa , Vallecillichthys multivertebratum , Robertichthys riograndensis , Rhynchodercetis regio , Pachycormidae indet., Pachyrhizodontidae indet.), indeterminate sea turtles, plesiosaurs (cf. Polycotylodon sp., Mauriciosaurus fernandezi ) and aigialosaurs ( Vallecillosaurus donrobertoi ) ( 32 , 34 - 36 ). Many of these fossils show exquisite soft tissue preservation. For further information on the geological, paleontological and paleoecological setting of the Vallecillo Lagerstätte, see ( 32 - 34 , 37 , 38 ).
Taphonomy

Several organisms, including the ammonite Pseudaspidoceras pseudonodosoides and various actinopterygian fishes ( Paranursallia gutturosa , Goulmimichthys roberti , Rhynchodercetis regio ), are preserved on the slab along with the holotype of Aquilolamnamilarcae (
). Specimen INAH 2544 P.F.17 shows some disarticulation of skeletal elements, notably jaw and pectoral girdle elements. Such moderate disarticulation is common at Vallecillo and mostly related to gas release during the decay process. No teeth can be observed in INAH 2544 P.F.17, possibly due to rapid post-mortem disarticulation and scattering affecting the dentition. Unlike in Aquilolamna , the dentitions can be observed in the few articulated specimens of other elasmobranch taxa (i.e., Ptychodus and Cretoxyrhina ) found at Vallecillo; however, these dentitions, preserved in slight to moderate disarticulation, consist of small to rather large teeth (~5 to 25 mm in maximum dimension). This taphonomic observation supports the hypothesis that Aquilolamna had a dentition with very small (<5 mm) dental elements that may have been winnowed.

Vallecillo vertebrate fossils show all stages of decay from complete specimens with skin shadow to isolated primary fragments. The loss or finding of isolated body parts like the tail and other fins, or elements of the skull, is explained by a failure of mechanically weak articulations due to progressive decay, because body parts are missing as a whole, without bite marks or traces of violent disruption. Slight dislocation of ribs is most plausibly explained by the disruption of the swim bladder or escape of decay gas from the body cavity, and not from currents or scavengers. Most missing body parts were lost during post-mortem drifting. There is no evidence for scavenger activities at the sea floor. Some carcasses sank to the sea bottom prior to decay, and disintegrated there out of the reach of other animals. Bite marks or broken bones were not identified among the Vallecillo vertebrate fossils, suggesting that scavenging upon carcasses at the sea-floor was uncommon or absent ( 32 , 34 , 39 ). The absence of scavengers and benthic life, with the exception of inoceramid bivalves, is explained by the anoxic conditions at the Vallecillo sea floor due to persistence of Oceanic Anoxic Event 2 ( 33 , 34 , 38 ). Apparently, carcasses were buried outside the reach of scavengers within the oxygen minimum zone.
Comparison with modern neoselachians

The measurement data for the extant species ( Tables S1 and S 2 ) used to assess the ecomorphotype of Aquilolamna milarcae were assembled from the literature ( 17 , 40 - 50 ). We followed Sternes and Shimadaʾs ( 51 ) strategy by using illustrations of reference books (i.e., FAO publications, authored by experts of international renown) to determine some morphometric measurements usually not provided in the literature and thus not available for all species. Interestingly, Sternes and Shimada ( 51 ) demonstrated the high degree of similarity between the book illustrations and actual shark samples, thus showing that such drawings can be reliably used for interspecific morphometric analyses. For each shark species included in the present analysis, illustrations in lateral and ventral views allowed to assess body proportions and to calculate the precaudal length (PCL), caudal fin length (CFL) and pectoral fin span (PFS) on the basis of the known maximum total length (TL). For each batoid species (except rhinopristiform species) included in the present analysis, we used either the known maximum disc width (DW, which corresponds to the PFS of sharks and rhinopristiform batoids) to calculate the disc length (DL), or the known maximum TL to calculate the disc length and disc width (using illustrations in dorsal view). In addition to the measurements of specimen INAH 2544 P.F.17, hypothetical measurements inferred from a 250 cm hypothetical maximum TL were used for A. milarcae . All measurements were log 10 -transformed in order to improve normality and homogeneity of variance. All analyses described below were performed using PAleontological STatistics (PAST software, version 4.04) ( 52 ).

In a first analysis, we compared Aquilolamna milarcae to 26 modern shark species belonging to the four specialized pelagic ecomorphotypes (i.e., bathic, microceanic, macroceanic, and tachypelagic) and to the specialized benthic ecomorphotype characterized by enlarged pectoral fins (i.e., squatinobenthic) ( 1 ) ( Table S1 ). For each ecomorphotype, we selected several species representative of the size range and body proportions of the category. As a multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) revealed significant differences in the multivariate means of the five ecomorphotypesconsideredtogether (Pillaiʾs trace = 1.826, F12, 63 = 8.169, p <0.0001) andin pairs ( Table S3 ), a linear discriminant analysis (LDA) was performed to compare the body proportions of Aquilolamna to those of modern sharks and to determine whether Aquilolamna falls into any of the ecomorphotypes. This method maximizes the separation between groups while minimizing the within-group variance. Here, the LDA matrix consists of three quantitative variables (PCL, CFL and PFS, all log 10 -transformed) and one qualitative variable (ecomorphotype category, here used as grouping variable) scored for 26 modern shark species (assigned to five given groups) plus A. milarcae (with no given group). As the ecomorphotype of the latter is unknown, a "?" was scored in the group column; thus, A. milarcae was not included in the discriminant analysis itself, but was classified.

In a second analysis, 27 modern batoid species belonging to the three main ecomorphotypes (i.e., aquilopelagic, rajobenthic, and rhinobenthic) ( 1 ) ( Table S2 ) were added to the previous data set. The taxonomy and maximum size of some species were updated following the 2016 book "Rays of the World" ( 53 ). As the slender tails (short to extremely long, sometimes whiplike with no caudal fin) of the batoids belonging to the rajobenthic and aquilopelagic ecomorphotypes cannot be compared with the caudal fins of sharks, the variable "CFL" was removed from this analysis. For each of the three added ecomorphotypes, we selected several species representative of the size range and body proportions of the category. As a multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) revealed significant differences in the multivariate means of the eight ecomorphotypes consideredtogether (Pillaiʾs trace = 1.537, F14, 90 = 21.32, p <0.0001) and in pairs ( Table S4 ), a linear discriminant analysis (LDA) was performed to compare the body proportions of Aquilolamna to those of modern neoselachians and to determine whether Aquilolamna falls into any of the ecomorphotypes. Here, the LDA matrix consists of two quantitative variables (PCL or DL, and PFS or DW, all log 10 -transformed) and one qualitative variable (ecomorphotype category, here used as grouping variable) scored for 53 modern neoselachian species (26 sharks and 27 batoids assigned to eight given groups) plus A. milarcae (with no given group). As the ecomorphotype of the latter is unknown, a "?" was scored in the group column; thus, A. milarcae was not included in the discriminant analysis itself, but was classified.

tp:taxon-treatment.tp:mixed-nomenclature: Aquilolamna milarcae gen. et sp. novEtymology

tp:treatment-sec.p: Generic name combines ʿ Aquila ʾ ( Latin , eagle), and the shark genus name ʿ Lamna ʾ, in reference to the wing-shaped pectoral fins and aquilopelagic ecomorphotype of this probable lamniform. Specific epithet refers to the Museo La Milarca (San Pedro Garza García, Nuevo León State , Mexico ), where the holotype is housed and exhibited. Proposed vernacular name: eagle shark.

tp:treatment-sec.p: Locality and horizon

Vallecillo quarry area, Nuevo León State , Mexico (
26.655° N ,
100.044° W ); Vallecillo Member of the Agua Nueva Formation, middle -upper Pseudaspidoceras flexuosum Zone, lower Turonian, Upper Cretaceous (
) ( 32 ). This stratigraphic level is ca. 93 million years in age.
Diagnosis of family, genus and species

Medium-sized neoselachian shark that differs from all other selachimorphs in having hypertrophied, scythe-shaped plesodic pectoral fins whose span exceeds the total length of the animal. High number (~70) of anteriorly directed pectoral radials. Head short and broad, with wide and near-terminal mouth. Caudal fin markedly heterocercal. Caudal fin skeleton showing a high hypochordal ray angle (i.e., ventrally directed hypochordal rays). Caudal tip slender with no (or strongly reduced?) terminal lobe. Squamation strongly reduced (or completely absent?).
Remark on Aquilolamnidae

The family Aquilolamnidae ( type and only known genus: Aquilolamna ) possibly includes the enigmatic, poorly known Late Cretaceous genera Cretomanta ( 24 ) and Platylithophycus ( 27 ). Systematic and paleoecological assumptions combined with stratigraphic evidence (see main text) suggest that the tooth-based genus Cretomanta is a suitable candidate for being the dental elements of the skeleton-based genus Aquilolamna (for which teeth are unknown in the sole specimen available to date) and thus may be a senior synonym of the latter; however, both taxa must be considered distinct pending the discovery of overlapping material.
Description

The holotype is a 166-cm-long (total length TL) holomorphic specimen with a precaudal length (PCL) of 122 cm and an estimated pectoral fin span (PFS) of about 190 cm ( 158 cm as preserved) (PFS about 1.1 times TL and 1.6 times PCL)
;
the specimen is preserved flattened dorsoventrally, with the exception of the tail exposed in lateral view (
)
. The vertebral column consists of about 225 asterospondylic vertebrae, with the caudal vertebral count (~120) higher than the precaudal vertebral count (~105) .
Anteriorly, there is no synarcual element, indicating that this specimen cannot be classified as a batoid ( 9 )
.
Tessellated prismatic calcified cartilage is well preserved in various parts of the specimen, with tesserae showing the sub-hexagonal close-packing arrangement typical of chondrichthyans ( 27 )
.
Soft-tissue imprints (skin, muscles) are preserved, providing information on the body outline (
and
and
to S6)
.
The skin seems to be overall devoid of dermal denticles, as in many myliobatiform rays ( 54 )
. The head is severely crushed dorsoventrally ;
it is short, with an indistinct snout and a wide mouth (
and
)
.
As indicated by the position of the anteriormost vertebra, the poorly preserved chondrocranium represents about 10% of the precaudal length. The overall outline of the chondrocranium is not recognizable, although some structures can be tentatively interpreted as rostral cartilages and nasal capsules. The jaws are long, extending posterior to the occiput. With the exception of a disarticulated and displaced Meckelʾs cartilage ( 259 mm in length), jaw elements cannot be identified with certainty, as those of hyoid and branchial arches. No teeth are preserved, possibly due to rapid post-mortem disarticulation and scattering affecting the dentition, like in fossil skeletons of cetorhinid sharks ( 55 , 56 )
.
The hyper-elongate pectoral fins are rather broad at their bases, slightly forward-directed, and gently recurved at their ends (
and
)
. They show an extremely increased number of radial cartilages. At least 70 radials are present , probably supported by several rodlike metapterygial elements. These radials are directed towards the anterior margin of the pectoral fin and some of them are bifurcated anteriorly (
), as in the megamouth shark ( 7 ). The trunk is moderately slender. No stomach/gut contents are preserved. There are no traces of dorsal, pelvic or anal fins; this reflects either original morphology (true phylogenetic absence) or taphonomic loss (post-mortem disarticulation and degradation). The caudal fin skeleton is characterized by ventrally directed hypochordal rays (hypochordal ray angle = 120°). The heterocercal caudal fin shows an elongate and slender dorsal lobe (dorsal margin length = 51 cm ) at a moderate angle above the body axis (heterocercal angle = 27°), and a rather strong ventral lobe (preventral margin length = 21 cm ) at a high angle below the body axis (hypocercal angle = 55°) ["lamniform caudal fin type 2" sensu ( 13 )]. No terminal lobe can be discerned at the caudal tip (
and
).
Remark on the caudal fin shape

Interestingly, the caudal fin shape of sharks is generally related to their primary habitat and lifestyle ( 1 , 57 ). Among modern sharks, four main types of caudal fin shape can be identified ( 57 ). The caudal fin type observed in Aquilolamna milarcae is present in most active-swimming littoral and oceanic species (e.g., Megachasmidae , Odontaspididae , Carcharhinidae ) ( 1 , 13 , 57 ). High-speed pelagic sharks with a tuna-like morphology ( Lamnidae ) have a crescentic, rather symmetrical caudal fin (i.e., high heterocercal and hypocercal angles) ( 1 , 13 , 57 ). Deepwater sharks such as Squaliformes generally have a caudal fin with a moderate to low heterocercal angle, a well-developed epichordal (= epicaudal) lobe, and a large terminal lobe ( 1 , 57 ). Lastly, bottom-dwelling sharks usually have a caudal fin characterized by a very low heterocercal angle and a poorly defined (or no separate) ventral lobe ( 1 , 57 ) (
).

In conclusion, the Megachasma -like caudal fin shape of Aquilolamna milarcae , well distinct from that of benthic species, strongly indicates that this shark was an active-swimming pelagic form (although not capable of high swimming speeds) (
).
Remark on the presence/absence of dorsal, pelvic and anal fins

As mentioned above, the apparent absence of dorsal, pelvic and anal fins in INAH 2544 P.F.17 reflects either original morphology or taphonomic loss. In modern sharks, the first dorsal fin is more or less developed ( 1 , 9 ). Among filter-feeding Lamniformes , the basking shark
( Cetorhinus maximus ; derived tachypelagic form) has a high, well-developed first dorsal fin, whereas the megamouth shark ( Megachasma pelagios ; macroceanic form) has a low, moderately large first dorsal fin ( 16 ). Interestingly, this is inversely proportional to the development of their pectoral fins. In Cetorhinus and Megachasma , the pectoral fin span represents 54% and 70% of the precaudal length, respectively (see
Table S 1
). Furthermore, the pectoral area is about equal to the first dorsal fin area in Cetorhinus , whereas the pectoral area is about triple the first dorsal fin area in Megachasma ( 16 ). Similarly, pelagic cownose, eagle and devil rays ( Rhinopteridae , Myliobatidae and Mobulidae ; aquilopelagic forms) have enlarged winglike pectoral fins and a small dorsal fin (despite the lack of caudal fin) ( 1 , 9 ). In analogy with modern elasmobranchs, the hyper-elongate pectoral fins of Aquilolamna would suggest that the first dorsal fin, if present, might have been small.

Whereas the anal fin was secondarily lost in many living sharks and all living batoids, pelvic fins are present in all modern elasmobranchs ( 9 , 10 ). Pelvic fins were not secondary lost because males have paired copulatory organs (claspers) whose cartilaginous elements correspond to a modified portion of the pelvic fin skeleton ( 9 ). Therefore, the apparent lack of pelvic fins in the holotype of Aquilolamna is most likely due to taphonomic loss. Only the discovery of new material may help determine whether Aquilolamna actually possessed dorsal, pelvic and anal fins.
Remark on the body size

The holotype and single known specimen of Aquilolamna milarcae is a medium-sized individual; however, it is not possible to determine 1) whether this specimen represents a juvenile, subadult or adult individual, and 2) the maximum size attainable by this species. Unfortunately, the origin and evolutionary history of Aquilolamnidae are undocumented, and we do not know if these putative lamniform sharks could reach gigantic sizes like in the four modern lineages of filter-feeding elasmobranchs (i.e., Rhincodontidae , Megachasmidae , Cetorhinidae , Mobulidae ) ( 3 ). If the enigmatic genus Platylithophycus (known by a single specimen representing a large individual) ( 27 ) can be proven to be actually an aquilolamnid, this would suggest an evolutionary pathway toward gigantism in this lineage of Late Cretaceous sharks.
